body:
Thanks for opening this issue. I've tried to reproduce this based on the provided repository, but for me it does not output 2 foreign keys.

Can you please verify that you:
* Use the latest version of diesel_cli
* That your example actually reproduces the issue
* Add more information about your environment (postgres version, â€¦)

I tried to reproduce here with @lochetti 's repo (me and him found this weird behavior together), and got the same results. The image I'm using is `docker.io/postgres:11.5-alpine`. The schema committed to repository is unchanged after db setup.

I have tested in various docker postgres images.

- docker.io/postgres:10 -> I was able to reproduce the problem
- docker.io/postgres:11 -> I was able to reproduce the problem
- docker.io/postgres:12 -> Don't show the error. Looks like it's ok.
- docker.io/postgres:13 -> Don't show the error. Looks like it's ok.
- docker.io/postgres:14 -> Don't show the error. Looks like it's ok.
- docker.io/postgres:15 -> Don't show the error. Looks like it's ok.

So, it looks like the problem only happens in versions older than 12.

Thanks for coming back to report that this is problem depending on the used postgres version. As this does only affect older postgres versions I do not consider that as a critical bug. I would accept a fix nevertheless as long as it does not break newer postgres versions.

The relevant code is here: 
https://github.com/diesel-rs/diesel/blob/027be9b155a3439ede6c947bd1de30cd8954c3c4/diesel_cli/src/infer_schema_internals/information_schema.rs#L191

This code loads the foreign key constraints from the information schema. We likely miss some condition there to make this work on older postgres version. It might be helpful to just dump the query via `diesel::debug_query` and try to modify the relevant parts in a local postgres command line. You don't need to run `diesel setup` anytime to reproduce the issue. `diesel print-schema` has the same behavior.

Thank you, for your reply!
Unfortunately, I could not only reproduce the bug on Postgres 15, but I could also show that the column chosen for the joinable definition also varies "arbitrarily".

I updated [the repository](https://github.com/lochetti/diesel_joinable_composite_fk), to show this in a clear manner. With this version, one could reproduce the problem in Postgres 15 (and 14 as well), which might show that the problem is bigger than antecipated.

Would you kindly try to reproduce with this new setup?
Thanks for the update. I was able to reproduce the described problem. See #3451 for a fix.
Thanks @weiznich ! Is there anything else that I could do to help?

@weiznich , I have looked and there are two things that I want to highlight:
1. I don't see, anymore, cases of composite foreign key creating joinables :)
2. But, I do see joinables being created for simple foreign keys on tables that also have composite foreign keys.

I actually liked this behaviour better, because we can have a simple and a composite foreign key between two tables AND still have the joinable being created for the simple foreign key. With that said, this might contradict the third bullet point that says that no joinable will be genarated when "There is more than one foreign key connecting two tables", as you can see [here](https://docs.diesel.rs/diesel/macro.joinable.html). 

Also I tested diesel setup on my real project using postgres 11 until 15, and all generated schemas file were the same.
@lochetti Thanks for checking out the fix and pointing out these issues. I've pushed another version which should address that as well.
Great! Let me know when I can test this new push.

@weiznich I have tested with the new push and now everything looks ok:
- I don't see, anymore, cases of composite foreign key creating joinables :)
- And, the third bullet point of the [documentation](https://docs.diesel.rs/diesel/macro.joinable.html) is respected.

Again, I have tested on my real project using postgres from 11 until 15.
